paragraphs.text: Why CIA interrogations report matters: Torture doesn't work and Americans need to know.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: As a former professional interviewer with the FBI, I know what works and doesn't
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Torture is not an effective way to get information
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the American people need to know that
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That's why the Senate Intelligence Committee report on CIA interrogation and detention after 9/11 is important
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The executive summary of the report, written after reviewing hundreds of thousands of the CIA's internal documents, shows that torture was more brutal and much less fruitful than the CIA claimed
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: In fact
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the committee concluded that all the claims about the value of intelligence gained from "enhanced" interrogation--including the claim that it helped the U.S  find Usama bin Laden-- are overstated or just plain false
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Proponents of torture are contesting these well-documented findings
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: So let's look at the facts
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: On 9/11, the CIA had few, if any, experienced counterterrorism interrogators
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Their traditional purview had been intelligence collection during the Cold War
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Inexperienced in this area and overwhelmed they resorted to techniques that merely sounded good but in fact worked against them
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: When concocting the legal opinions to authorize torture, the lawyers inside our government didn't consult trained interviewers or interrogation experts--the people who actually knew how to get information
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: They consulted psychologists who helped train U.S  military pilots to resist torture methods should they be captured
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: (torture methods, it should be noted, designed to elicit false confessions)
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: they had consulted trained interviewers
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: they would have found out what I and my colleagues had known for decades: Torture isn't just unnecessary; it's an unreliable way to get information
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Instead
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: as the Senate report shows, the CIA brought in untrained interrogators and contractors and asked them to get answers out of Al Qaeda detainees using methods designed to inflict pain, both physical and mental, and even simulate death
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The CIA also employed horrific methods, like forced rectal feedings, that were never approved
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: I recall when I learned that cruel techniques were being used
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: I spoke with several long-term CIA officers and CIA polygraph experts with whom I had worked over many years
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: we were all appalled
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: not just by its immorality
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: because we knew it would be counterproductive
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Apologists say that these methods were used to put the detainees into a state of "learned helplessness," in which the detainee would depend totally on his captor and give up all information
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Those of us who have actually conducted interviews know that this isn't the way things work
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: To get good, accurate information, you want the subject to be as cognizant as possible
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: You want him to be able to remember all the details and to be able to tell you them
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: A person will say anything to try to stop the pain
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: torture impairs the suspect's ability to remember the details that may be essential to your investigation
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Professionals don't need to use torture and never have
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: On top of that, torture is illegal, both here in the U.S  and internationally
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The United States has even prosecuted people for the methods that the CIA used after 9/11
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: We are a nation of laws
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the conduct detailed in the Senate report is against the law
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: For these reasons, in October, I joined 22 other security, interrogation and interviewing experts to issue a statement of principles in opposition to using torture
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Not only is torture less reliable, illegal and immoral, we write
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it also makes our nation less safe
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: When we are not using effective and legal interviewing tactics, we miss information that may be vital to our nation's safety
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: In using torture, we also encourage other nations and actors (including terrorist groups) to emulate our illegal actions, effectively lowering the bar for the rest of the world, and allow them to use U.S  torture as a recruiting tool
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: President Obama, on his second day in office, signed an executive order banning the CIA torture methods the Senate report describes
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: But this executive order could be overturned by a future president
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Now that the Senate report's executive summary has been released and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the public knows the just how ineffective and brutal U.S  torture was, we need to make sure that this prohibition is permanent
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Working with Congress to pass legislation that makes sure a ban on torture extends to the CIA is one way that President Obama can make sure that the United States never again embraces the misguided, ineffective, and dangerous tactics of torture
paragraphs.label: assumption
